item.title: GOP Health Bill Draft Would Cut Medicaid, Emphasize Tax Credits
item.description: February 24, 2017 - The plan would replace insurance subsidies for low-income families with tax credits for everyone, eliminate the requirement to buy health care, and end taxes on medical devices.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - The plan would replace insurance subsidies for low-income families with tax credits for everyone, eliminate the requirement to buy health care, and end taxes on medical devices. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/24/517074764/gop-health-bill-draft-would-cut-medicaid-emphasize-tax-credits

item.title: Advice From Patients On A Study's Design Makes For Better Science
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Increasingly, advocates for patients are in the room when big medical studies are designed. They demand answers to big questions: "Will the results of this study actually help anybody?"
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Increasingly, advocates for patients are in the room when big medical studies are designed. They demand answers to big questions: "Will the results of this study actually help anybody?" http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/24/515226648/advice-from-patients-on-a-studys-design-makes-for-better-science

item.title: Environmental Groups Say California's Climate Program Has Not Helped Them
item.description: February 24, 2017 - California's signature climate plan is under attack from environmental justice groups. Some say the cap-and-trade program hasn't done anything to clean up the air in low-income communities.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - California's signature climate plan is under attack from environmental justice groups. Some say the cap-and-trade program hasn't done anything to clean up the air in low-income communities. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/24/515379885/environmental-groups-say-californias-climate-program-has-not-helped-them

item.title: Kevin Jones: Can Embracing Uncertainty Lead To Better Medicine?
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Sometimes, doctors just don't have the answers. Surgeon Kevin Jones says having the humility to acknowledge this leads to better medicine.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Sometimes, doctors just don't have the answers. Surgeon Kevin Jones says having the humility to acknowledge this leads to better medicine. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/24/516710048/kevin-jones-can-embracing-uncertainty-lead-to-better-medicine

item.title: Indiana's Claims About Its Medicaid Experiment Don't All Check Out
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Indiana's health program for low-income people is experimental, and needs federal approval to continue. The state says its program is working, but some claims lack much-needed context.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Indiana's health program for low-income people is experimental, and needs federal approval to continue. The state says its program is working, but some claims lack much-needed context. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/24/516704082/indiana-s-claims-about-its-medicaid-program-dont-all-check-out

item.title: White House Spokesman Predicts More Federal Action Against Marijuana
item.description: February 23, 2017 - Press secretary Sean Spicer's comments on Thursday came as a poll indicated a majority of Americans support legalizing marijuana.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - Press secretary Sean Spicer's comments on Thursday came as a poll indicated a majority of Americans support legalizing marijuana. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/23/516945294/white-house-spokesman-predicts-more-federal-action-against-marijuana

item.title: Some Teachers, Principals And Students Condemn Trump Transgender Policy
item.description: February 23, 2017 - Supporters say it was wrong to force local schools to allow transgender students to choose which bathroom to use. Critics say rescinding that policy empowers those who harass transgender kids.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - Supporters say it was wrong to force local schools to allow transgender students to choose which bathroom to use. Critics say rescinding that policy empowers those who harass transgender kids. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/23/516878336/some-teachers-principals-and-students-condemn-trump-transgender-policy

item.title: Who Declares A Famine? And What Does That Actually Mean?
item.description:
February 23, 2017 - Just as we rank hurricanes and earthquakes, officials have developed a five-phase scale to rank food crises.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/02/23/516642447/who-declares-a-famine-and-what-does-that-actually-mean
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Arkansas Supreme Court Strikes Down Local Anti-Discrimination Law
item.description: February 23, 2017 - The court ruled that a Fayetteville, Ark., law protecting LGBT people violated a state law barring cities from protecting people from discrimination who are not already covered at the state level.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - The court ruled that a Fayetteville, Ark., law protecting LGBT people violated a state law barring cities from protecting people from discrimination who are not already covered at the state level. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/23/516702975/arkansas-supreme-court-strikes-down-local-anti-discrimination-law

item.title: Ice Fishing Has Its Rewards, But Bring A First Aid Kit
item.description: February 23, 2017 - Every winter people flock to the frigid lakes of Canada and the northern U.S.A. to ice fish. According to a new study, thislow and seemingly harmless sport has some risks of injuries.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - Every winter people flock to the frigid lakes of Canada and the northern U.S.A. to ice fish. According to a new study, thislow and seemingly harmless sport has some risks of injuries. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/23/516701563/ice-fishing-has-its-rewards-but-bring-a-first-aid-kit

item.title: To Test Zika Vaccines, Scientists Need A New Outbreak
item.description: February 23, 2017 - It's a bit of a paradox, but researchers say they need Zika virus to re-emerge this year so they can test vaccines designed to defeat it.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - It's a bit of a paradox, but researchers say they need Zika virus to re-emerge this year so they can test vaccines designed to defeat it. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/23/516822252/to-test-zika-vaccines-scientists-need-a-new-outbreak

item.title: Poverty Plus A Poisonous Plant Blamed For Paralysis In Rural Africa
item.description: February 23, 2017 - Some African countries have long witnessed mysterious outbreaks of paralysis. Affected regions are poor and conflict-ridden, where people's main food is a bitter, poisonous variety of cassava.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - Some African countries have long witnessed mysterious outbreaks of paralysis. Affected regions are poor and conflict-ridden, where people's main food is a bitter, poisonous variety of cassava. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/23/515819034/poverty-plus-a-poisonous-plant-blamed-for-paralysis-in-rural-africa

item.title: What's Next For The Affordable Care Act? Your Questions Answered
item.description: February 23, 2017 - A lot of people are confused about when and if Republicans can "repeal and replace" the Affordable Care Act. Kaiser Health News' Julie Rovner clears things up in the first of a series.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - A lot of people are confused about when and if Republicans can "repeal and replace" the Affordable Care Act. Kaiser Health News' Julie Rovner clears things up in the first of a series. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/23/516697149/whats-next-for-the-affordable-care-act-your-questions-answered

item.title: Should Scientists March? U.S. Researchers Still Debating Pros And Cons
item.description: February 23, 2017 - A "March for Science" is set for April 22 in Washington, D.C., to show support for evidence-based public policy. But some worry the march will be seen as partisan, and may even undermine sound policy.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 23, 2017 - A "March for Science" is set for April 22 in Washington, D.C., to show support for evidence-based public policy. But some worry the march will be seen as partisan, and may even undermine sound policy. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/23/515584634/should-scientists-march-u-s-researchers-still-debating-pros-and-cons

item.title: Trump Administration Rescinds Obama Rule On Transgender Students' Bathroom Use
item.description: February 22, 2017 - The administration will not direct public schools to allow students to use facilities that match their gender identities. It notes the primary role of state and local districts in education policy.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 22, 2017 - The administration will not direct public schools to allow students to use facilities that match their gender identities. It notes the primary role of state and local districts in education policy. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/22/516664633/trump-administration-rescinds-obama-rule-on-transgender-students-bathroom-use
